issue.title: Providing vpc_subnet_id, but  failing one get_default_subnet

My molecule yaml looks like this (redacted IDs):
```
---
dependency:
  name: galaxy
driver:
  name: ec2
platforms:
  - name: instance
    image_id: ami-abc123abc123
    instance_type: t2.micro
    region: us-east-1
    vpc_id: vpc-abc123abc123
    vpc_subnet_id: subnet-abc123abc123
    tags:
      - Name: molecule_instance
provisioner:
  name: ansible
verifier:
  name: ansible

```

comment.body: What I have just found on 0.4 is that you are supposed to only pass `vpc_subnet_id` if you want to use a custom subnet id. Adding on top `vpc_id` will make it fail, because it will assume that you want to auto-create it in that case. Just removing `vpc_id` did work for me.

issue.title: os_auth_retries variable causes a comparison type error on pam_debian.yml
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

When calling the role os_hardening passing the variable `os_auth_retries` defined in `vars` as part of `include_role`, some comparison guards in `pam_debian.yml` cause an exception. It appears that the variable passed via `vars` is a string, but the comparison guards expect an int without type casting it.

Example case:

```yaml
- name: "Run dev-sec os-hardening"
  ansible.builtin.include_role:
    name: devsec.hardening.os_hardening
  vars:
    os_auth_retries: "{{ some_dict.os_auth_retries }}"
```

```yaml
some_dict:
  os_auth_retries: 10
```

this produces:

```log
fatal: [instance]: FAILED! => {"msg": "The conditional check 'os_auth_retries > 0' failed. The error was: Unexpected templating type error occurred on ({% if os_auth_retries > 0 %} True {% else %} False {% endif %}): '>' not supported between instances of 'AnsibleUnsafeText' and 'int'\n\nThe error appears to be in '/home/user/.cache/ansible-compat/f22a9c/collections/ansible_collections/devsec/hardening/roles/os_hardening/tasks/pam_debian.yml': line 20, column 3, but may\nbe elsewhere in the file depending on the exact syntax problem.\n\nThe offending line appears to be:\n\n\n- name: Install tally2\n  ^ here\n"}
```

According to some ansible upstream issues, the actual role code should be the one doing the type casting to the expected type, see e.g. https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/13574#issuecomment-174639586

Indeed, manually modifying the local checkout of the os_hardening role and modifying the entries to use the following does solve the problem:

```yaml
  when:
    - os_auth_retries | int > 0
...
      when:
        - os_auth_retries | int > 0
...
      when:
        - os_auth_retries | int == 0
```

I could provide a patch but I'd just like to get first a heads-up about the approach. Thanks!

**OS / Environment**

macOS 12.6

**Ansible Version**

```paste below
ansible [core 2.12.2]
  config file = None
  configured module search path = ['/home/user/.ansible/plugins/modules', '/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible
  ansible collection location = /home/user/.ansible/collections:/usr/share/ansible/collections
  executable location = /home/user/.local/bin/ansible
  python version = 3.10.2 (main, Feb 21 2022, 16:34:42) [Clang 13.0.0 (clang-1300.0.29.30)]
  jinja version = 3.0.3
  libyaml = True
```

**Role Version**

```paste below
8.1.0
```

comment.body: Actually this also affects redhat pam files, I just had not experienced it yet because the way I was disabling some settings.

issue.title: Specify extra claims to fields stored in session-cookie-minimal
issue.body:
## Current Behavior
You recently introduced session-cookie-minimal ( in
[Add option to remove tokens from cookie sessions #673](https://github.com/oauth2-proxy/oauth2-proxy/pull/673) )

Btw, It **should be mentioned in the documentation**, especially if you consider to make it as a default.



When this flag is specified, currently  it’s not possible to include in the session any claims normally available in id_token.

Existing hardcoded fields (Email: User: Groups:[] PreferredUsername) in  SessionState often  not sufficient and not extendable.

## Expected Behavior

It will be good to include in configuration   session-cookie-minimal-extra-claims=“claim1name,claim2name” that will allow to specify extra claims, stored within a session.
That should add to the SessionState ExtraClaims field as a collection of claims copied from id_token.

## Possible Solution

The extra claims will be included as header(s) to upstreams.
Not sure will it be better to have one header “extra-claims” passing collection or pass separate header for each claim
## Context

I want to pass as header a couple of proprietary claims, but don’t want to to keep in cookie the whole big id_token
## Your Environment

Fork of oaut2proxy v7, March 2021, Azure AD B2C

comment.body: This is still an issue

-      - uses: actions/setup-node@v2
+      - uses: actions/setup-node@v3
         with:
           node-version: '16'
+      - name: Setup required upstream yarn version
+        run: yarn set version 1.22.5

issue.title: got error with self-hosted sentry
issue.body:
Hey, I tried to apply this provider in my self-hosted sentry, following this guide https://develop.sentry.dev/self-hosted/

Simply added `pip install sentry-auth-oidc` in `enhance-image.sh` and ran `./install.sh`, but it failed and I got error as follows：

```
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oidc/apps.py", line 10, in ready
    from .provider import OIDCProvider
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oidc/provider.py", line 17, in <module>
    from .views import FetchUser, OIDCConfigureView
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oidc/views.py", line 5, in <module>
    from sentry.utils.compat import map
ImportError: cannot import name 'map' from 'sentry.utils.compat' (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sentry/utils/compat/__init__.py)
An error occurred, caught SIGERR on line 13
```

I wonder if was cause by the mismatch of sentry version, or maybe i did something wrong with these steps, any clues?

comment.body: @lucifan Thanks for the heads-up, it's good to know we are not the only users 😆 We started some work already in #33 and we should be ready in the next days.

issue.title: refactor: adapt to sentry 22.8

comment.body:
@max-wittig I've solved multiple issues with the test build due to outdated node & python versions, but looks like there's some fundamental issue with how tests are launched in the most recent sentry versions. Any quick idea what is wrong without me having to make a full download of the sentry sources and setup locally a dev environment?

As far as I can see we are pointing to sentry@latest, which maybe is not the best approach and we should test against a specific version to guarantee compatibility? (or maybe a matrix of them)

issue.body:
controller-manager 's config flag `--terminated-pod-gc-threshold ` currently has a default value of `12500` - that's quite a lot! 


/sig apps 
/kind bug

comment.body:
@alculquicondor Hey, thanks for the answer. Not an issue on our end, we can ofc modify the defaults. It's even mentioned on the [CIS hardening for k3s](https://rancher.com/docs/k3s/latest/en/security/hardening_guide/#control-1-3-1), as this might be a too-high value for certain environments.

But since I don't know all implications of that change, and the docs do not explain it in detail, this feedback is actually kind-of what I was looking for 😀

comment.body: What I have just found on 0.4 is that you are supposed to only pass `vpc_subnet_id` if you want to use a custom subnet id. Adding on top `vpc_id` will make it fail, because it will assume that you want to auto-create it in that case. Just removing `vpc_id` did work for me.

issue.title: os_auth_retries variable causes a comparison type error on pam_debian.yml
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

When calling the role os_hardening passing the variable `os_auth_retries` defined in `vars` as part of `include_role`, some comparison guards in `pam_debian.yml` cause an exception. It appears that the variable passed via `vars` is a string, but the comparison guards expect an int without type casting it.

Example case:

```yaml
- name: "Run dev-sec os-hardening"
  ansible.builtin.include_role:
    name: devsec.hardening.os_hardening
  vars:
    os_auth_retries: "{{ some_dict.os_auth_retries }}"
```

```yaml
some_dict:
  os_auth_retries: 10
```

this produces:

```log
fatal: [instance]: FAILED! => {"msg": "The conditional check 'os_auth_retries > 0' failed. The error was: Unexpected templating type error occurred on ({% if os_auth_retries > 0 %} True {% else %} False {% endif %}): '>' not supported between instances of 'AnsibleUnsafeText' and 'int'\n\nThe error appears to be in '/home/user/.cache/ansible-compat/f22a9c/collections/ansible_collections/devsec/hardening/roles/os_hardening/tasks/pam_debian.yml': line 20, column 3, but may\nbe elsewhere in the file depending on the exact syntax problem.\n\nThe offending line appears to be:\n\n\n- name: Install tally2\n  ^ here\n"}
```

According to some ansible upstream issues, the actual role code should be the one doing the type casting to the expected type, see e.g. https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/13574#issuecomment-174639586

Indeed, manually modifying the local checkout of the os_hardening role and modifying the entries to use the following does solve the problem:

```yaml
  when:
    - os_auth_retries | int > 0
...
      when:
        - os_auth_retries | int > 0
...
      when:
        - os_auth_retries | int == 0
```

I could provide a patch but I'd just like to get first a heads-up about the approach. Thanks!

**OS / Environment**

macOS 12.6

**Ansible Version**

```paste below
ansible [core 2.12.2]
  config file = None
  configured module search path = ['/home/user/.ansible/plugins/modules', '/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible
  ansible collection location = /home/user/.ansible/collections:/usr/share/ansible/collections
  executable location = /home/user/.local/bin/ansible
  python version = 3.10.2 (main, Feb 21 2022, 16:34:42) [Clang 13.0.0 (clang-1300.0.29.30)]
  jinja version = 3.0.3
  libyaml = True
```

**Role Version**

```paste below
8.1.0
```

comment.body: Actually this also affects redhat pam files, I just had not experienced it yet because the way I was disabling some settings.

issue.title: Specify extra claims to fields stored in session-cookie-minimal
issue.body:
## Current Behavior
You recently introduced session-cookie-minimal ( in
[Add option to remove tokens from cookie sessions #673](https://github.com/oauth2-proxy/oauth2-proxy/pull/673) )

Btw, It **should be mentioned in the documentation**, especially if you consider to make it as a default.



When this flag is specified, currently  it’s not possible to include in the session any claims normally available in id_token.

Existing hardcoded fields (Email: User: Groups:[] PreferredUsername) in  SessionState often  not sufficient and not extendable.

## Expected Behavior

It will be good to include in configuration   session-cookie-minimal-extra-claims=“claim1name,claim2name” that will allow to specify extra claims, stored within a session.
That should add to the SessionState ExtraClaims field as a collection of claims copied from id_token.

## Possible Solution

The extra claims will be included as header(s) to upstreams.
Not sure will it be better to have one header “extra-claims” passing collection or pass separate header for each claim
## Context

I want to pass as header a couple of proprietary claims, but don’t want to to keep in cookie the whole big id_token
## Your Environment

Fork of oaut2proxy v7, March 2021, Azure AD B2C

issue.title: got error with self-hosted sentry
issue.body:
Hey, I tried to apply this provider in my self-hosted sentry, following this guide https://develop.sentry.dev/self-hosted/

Simply added `pip install sentry-auth-oidc` in `enhance-image.sh` and ran `./install.sh`, but it failed and I got error as follows：

```
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oidc/apps.py", line 10, in ready
    from .provider import OIDCProvider
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oidc/provider.py", line 17, in <module>
    from .views import FetchUser, OIDCConfigureView
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oidc/views.py", line 5, in <module>
    from sentry.utils.compat import map
ImportError: cannot import name 'map' from 'sentry.utils.compat' (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sentry/utils/compat/__init__.py)
An error occurred, caught SIGERR on line 13
```

I wonder if was cause by the mismatch of sentry version, or maybe i did something wrong with these steps, any clues?

comment.body: @lucifan Thanks for the heads-up, it's good to know we are not the only users 😆 We started some work already in #33 and we should be ready in the next days.

comment.body:
@max-wittig I've solved multiple issues with the test build due to outdated node & python versions, but looks like there's some fundamental issue with how tests are launched in the most recent sentry versions. Any quick idea what is wrong without me having to make a full download of the sentry sources and setup locally a dev environment?

As far as I can see we are pointing to sentry@latest, which maybe is not the best approach and we should test against a specific version to guarantee compatibility? (or maybe a matrix of them)

controller-manager 's config flag `--terminated-pod-gc-threshold ` currently has a default value of `12500` - that's quite a lot! 


/sig apps

comment.body:
@alculquicondor Hey, thanks for the answer. Not an issue on our end, we can ofc modify the defaults. It's even mentioned on the [CIS hardening for k3s](https://rancher.com/docs/k3s/latest/en/security/hardening_guide/#control-1-3-1), as this might be a too-high value for certain environments.

But since I don't know all implications of that change, and the docs do not explain it in detail, this feedback is actually kind-of what I was looking for 😀

comment.body: What I have just found on 0.4 is that you are supposed to only pass `vpc_subnet_id` if you want to use a custom subnet id. Adding on top `vpc_id` will make it fail, because it will assume that you want to auto-create it in that case. Just removing `vpc_id` did work for me.

issue.title: os_auth_retries variable causes a comparison type error on pam_debian.yml
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

When calling the role os_hardening passing the variable `os_auth_retries` defined in `vars` as part of `include_role`, some comparison guards in `pam_debian.yml` cause an exception. It appears that the variable passed via `vars` is a string, but the comparison guards expect an int without type casting it.

Example case:

```yaml
- name: "Run dev-sec os-hardening"
  ansible.builtin.include_role:
    name: devsec.hardening.os_hardening
  vars:
    os_auth_retries: "{{ some_dict.os_auth_retries }}"
```

```yaml
some_dict:
  os_auth_retries: 10
```

this produces:

```log
fatal: [instance]: FAILED! => {"msg": "The conditional check 'os_auth_retries > 0' failed. The error was: Unexpected templating type error occurred on ({% if os_auth_retries > 0 %} True {% else %} False {% endif %}): '>' not supported between instances of 'AnsibleUnsafeText' and 'int'\n\nThe error appears to be in '/home/user/.cache/ansible-compat/f22a9c/collections/ansible_collections/devsec/hardening/roles/os_hardening/tasks/pam_debian.yml': line 20, column 3, but may\nbe elsewhere in the file depending on the exact syntax problem.\n\nThe offending line appears to be:\n\n\n- name: Install tally2\n  ^ here\n"}
```

According to some ansible upstream issues, the actual role code should be the one doing the type casting to the expected type, see e.g. https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/13574#issuecomment-174639586

Indeed, manually modifying the local checkout of the os_hardening role and modifying the entries to use the following does solve the problem:

```yaml
  when:
    - os_auth_retries | int > 0
...
      when:
        - os_auth_retries | int > 0
...
      when:
        - os_auth_retries | int == 0
```

I could provide a patch but I'd just like to get first a heads-up about the approach. Thanks!

**OS / Environment**

macOS 12.6

**Ansible Version**

```paste below
ansible [core 2.12.2]
  config file = None
  configured module search path = ['/home/user/.ansible/plugins/modules', '/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible
  ansible collection location = /home/user/.ansible/collections:/usr/share/ansible/collections
  executable location = /home/user/.local/bin/ansible
  python version = 3.10.2 (main, Feb 21 2022, 16:34:42) [Clang 13.0.0 (clang-1300.0.29.30)]
  jinja version = 3.0.3
  libyaml = True
```

**Role Version**

```paste below
8.1.0
```

comment.body: Actually this also affects redhat pam files, I just had not experienced it yet because the way I was disabling some settings.

issue.title: Specify extra claims to fields stored in session-cookie-minimal
issue.body:
## Current Behavior
You recently introduced session-cookie-minimal ( in
[Add option to remove tokens from cookie sessions #673](https://github.com/oauth2-proxy/oauth2-proxy/pull/673) )

Btw, It **should be mentioned in the documentation**, especially if you consider to make it as a default.



When this flag is specified, currently  it’s not possible to include in the session any claims normally available in id_token.

Existing hardcoded fields (Email: User: Groups:[] PreferredUsername) in  SessionState often  not sufficient and not extendable.

## Expected Behavior

It will be good to include in configuration   session-cookie-minimal-extra-claims=“claim1name,claim2name” that will allow to specify extra claims, stored within a session.
That should add to the SessionState ExtraClaims field as a collection of claims copied from id_token.

## Possible Solution

The extra claims will be included as header(s) to upstreams.
Not sure will it be better to have one header “extra-claims” passing collection or pass separate header for each claim
## Context

I want to pass as header a couple of proprietary claims, but don’t want to to keep in cookie the whole big id_token
## Your Environment

Fork of oaut2proxy v7, March 2021, Azure AD B2C

issue.title: got error with self-hosted sentry
issue.body:
Hey, I tried to apply this provider in my self-hosted sentry, following this guide https://develop.sentry.dev/self-hosted/

Simply added `pip install sentry-auth-oidc` in `enhance-image.sh` and ran `./install.sh`, but it failed and I got error as follows：

```
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oidc/apps.py", line 10, in ready
    from .provider import OIDCProvider
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oidc/provider.py", line 17, in <module>
    from .views import FetchUser, OIDCConfigureView
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oidc/views.py", line 5, in <module>
    from sentry.utils.compat import map
ImportError: cannot import name 'map' from 'sentry.utils.compat' (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sentry/utils/compat/__init__.py)
An error occurred, caught SIGERR on line 13
```

I wonder if was cause by the mismatch of sentry version, or maybe i did something wrong with these steps, any clues?

comment.body: @lucifan Thanks for the heads-up, it's good to know we are not the only users 😆 We started some work already in #33 and we should be ready in the next days.

issue.title: refactor: adapt to sentry 22.8

comment.body:
@max-wittig I've solved multiple issues with the test build due to outdated node & python versions, but looks like there's some fundamental issue with how tests are launched in the most recent sentry versions. Any quick idea what is wrong without me having to make a full download of the sentry sources and setup locally a dev environment?

As far as I can see we are pointing to sentry@latest, which maybe is not the best approach and we should test against a specific version to guarantee compatibility? (or maybe a matrix of them)

issue.body:
controller-manager 's config flag `--terminated-pod-gc-threshold ` currently has a default value of `12500` - that's quite a lot! 


/sig apps 
/kind bug

comment.body:
@alculquicondor Hey, thanks for the answer. Not an issue on our end, we can ofc modify the defaults. It's even mentioned on the [CIS hardening for k3s](https://rancher.com/docs/k3s/latest/en/security/hardening_guide/#control-1-3-1), as this might be a too-high value for certain environments.

But since I don't know all implications of that change, and the docs do not explain it in detail, this feedback is actually kind-of what I was looking for 😀
